text: today on x cast colonel moammar l
Qaddafi's interior minister flies to
cairo in a possible defection
coordinated attacks across Iraq raise
questions about the country's ability to
maintain security and over the weekend
three main Republican presidential
candidates emerge Michele Bachmann Rick
Perry and Mitt Romney we have a new
arrival here today in Cairo the interior
minister of the government of Colonel
Muammar al-gaddafi Nasser I'm abric
Abdullah arrived in Cairo today with his
family the Ambassador was surprised by a
visit and there's no indication
whatsoever that he's here on official
business in fact it looks very much like
another high-level defection his
departure comes at a time when the
rebels challenging Colonel Qaddafi's
forty years in power are once again on
the move after weeks of apparent
stalemate the rebels from the western
mountains inside Libya have moved in and
taken control of much of the pivotal
town of Zaire which is an
extraordinarily important town in the
geography of Libya it's right on the
doorstep of the capital about 30 miles
from Qaddafi's headquarters it's also an
important oil port and refinery where
they get much of the fuel and they're
running out of fuel right now in Tripoli
and it's on the road from the border of
Tunisia so it's the main supply line for
Qaddafi in Tripoli since the very
beginning of the uprising when all of
Libya rose up against Colonel Qaddafi in
late February this is the first time
that the rebels have been so close to
his stronghold and it's also the first
time in months that we've seen again
signs of splintering inside the regime
in this case the defection of the
interior minister for many rebels it
certainly raised hopes that they may
actually be closer than ever before to
toppling Colonel Qaddafi
Monday is the most violent day in Iraq
this year as insurgents launch attacks
across the country killing 68 people and
wounding over 300 the attacks came in
all parts of the country and appeared to
be targeted at Iraqi security forces not
a particular sect like the Sunnis were
the Shias on a typical day there's
usually 14 attacks across all of Iraq
but today there were nearly 40 which is
in a remarkable jump considering the
fact that violence had been declining
here for the past few months one of the
more interesting things I came across
today were statements from a member of
parliament who criticized the Iraqi
government which has claimed for months
that they have the capability to protect
their internal security the member of
parliament said that the Iraqi security
forces lacked the intelligence
capabilities to stop any types of
attacks and that the insurgents continue
to operate on their own without any fear
of the security forces
the biggest question for the Iraqi
government is whether to ask the United
States to keep some of their troops here
after the end of the year
the violence today will certainly give
the United States a little leverage with
the Iraqis when they sit down at the
negotiating tables the United States can
point to today as an example of how the
Iraqi security forces still need the
United States to provide them with
intelligence and help with
counterterrorism and Rick Perry changes
the dynamic in the Republican
presidential race we're here in Waterloo
Iowa where Governor Rick Perry of Texas
has started the first trip of his
presidential campaign a three-day swing
through Iowa I've got two they're
actually here three people came to
Waterloo Iowa today Governor Rick Perry
of Texas Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania
and Michelle Bachmann who's from
Waterloo but the focus was on Rick Perry
and Michelle Bachman the newest rivals
in what is expected to be a heated
battle for Iowa sometimes it kind of
takes me a while to get into something
like this presidential race but let me
tell you when I'm in I'm in all the way
what had been anticipated was the two of
them in the same room together providing
the first glimpse of an interaction
between them but it never took place mr.
Perry gave his speech in his Bachmann
hadn't even arrived yet
when he finished he went back to his
table and watched very politely as MS
Bachmann came in gave her speech and
never once acknowledging that he was
sitting at the table just a few feet
away when she finished her speech mr.
Perry the governor slipped out a side
entrance as she was signing t-shirts and
other memorabilia for the crowd not not
yet this was an in essence a kind of the
kickoff you had the straw poll on
Saturday and then this kicks off really
starts what is expected to be a real
intense battle between both of them for
Iowa and especially for the evangelical
and social conservatives of Iowa that
have been so much the mainstay of
Michele Bachmann support but that people
think Rick Perry might have a chance of
getting as well he's going to be a
strong campaigner he's going to be a
strong voice in the campaign I think
he's gonna have a lot to say and he made
what this weekend has done is now set up
a new dynamic between three candidates
Michele Bachmann Rick Perry and Mitt
Romney each of these candidates now have
serious challenges ahead of them
